quote: Captain's log, Stardate 43779.3.   The Enterprise is preparing   detailed atmospheric charts of the   Hayashi system. Although tedious,   this endeavor is the first step   toward planet colonization.
Sensors report the USS Hood   closing on an intercept course   at high warp.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: That's odd... I wasn't notified   of a rendezvous.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: They seem to be in an awful hurry.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Sir, we are being hailed on a   secured channel by Captain DeSoto.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: On screen.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Sorry to sneak up on you like   that, Jean-Luc --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Robert, why didn't you inform   us --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: -- Out here, you never know   who's listening. Keeps you on   your toes, anyway. Hey, Will,   you getting soft on that luxury   liner?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: So, old friend. How are you?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Ah, you know, they send you   Galaxy-Class boys out here to the   far reaches. Me, I'm hauling my   butt back and forth between   starbases --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: But not today.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Nope. Starfleet's got new orders   for you. This is top priority.   They need the fastest ship in   the fleet -- and the best people.   That's you.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: If time is so important, why   didn't they transmit the orders   by subspace?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: They're worried about Romulan   eavesdropping on this one. And   we've got a passenger for you.   Hard to send by subspace.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: What sort of passenger?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Mission specialist. He'll bring   your orders aboard with him.   Name's Tam Elbrun.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Elbrun? You mean Tam Elbrun as   in the Ghorusda disaster?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: The same.       What can I say? Your orders are   to cooperate fully with him.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Best of luck, folks. Hood out.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Sir, the Hood is slowing to   impulse.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Mister Data, come with me --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Captain, let me come with you to   greet Tam --
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: You know him?
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: I do... He was at the university   on Betazed when I studied   psychology there.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Ah, I see. He was a colleague,   then.
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: No, sir. He was a patient...
scene: 2    INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - WIDE ANGLE

quote: Tam is a telepath of extraordinary   talent, even for a Betazoid. He's   a specialist in first contact with   new life-forms, and... a rather   unique person.       He's not what you might expect,   Captain.
scene: 14   INT. CORRIDOR - TRACKING SHOT - PICARD, TROI AND DATA

quote: Welcome aboard the Enterprise.   I'm --
Captain Picard. Here --
You want to know all about your   mission. Everything's on there.   Orders and briefings. Destination   and heading, all that.
I sensed you were out here.   How've you been?
(embarrassed by Tam's     tactlessness, she still     can't help smiling)   Fine, but Tam, I...
Sir --
Who -- what are you?
My name is Data.
Incredible, an android. I can't   read you at all. It's like you're   not there.
Oh. You better hurry up to the   bridge with that. Captain wants   you to run the orders, scan the   technical schematics, and be ready   to brief him in ten minutes.       Right?
Number One?
Riker here.
Meet Mister Data on the bridge.   He has our orders and new heading.
Aye, sir.
And assemble the bridge staff for   a mission briefing in -- fifteen   minutes. Picard out.       Mister Elbrun. Would you --
Like to see my quarters. No.   I'd rather get this briefing over   with. Then be left alone until   I'm needed.
I've heard something about   Ghorusda. Weren't about forty   people killed --
scene: 19   INT. CORRIDOR - TRACKING SHOT - RIKER AND GEORDI

quote: Forty-seven, including the captain   of the Adelphi -- and two friends   from my class at the Academy.
scene: 19   INT. CORRIDOR - TRACKING SHOT - RIKER AND GEORDI

quote: Sorry. What happened?
scene: 19   INT. CORRIDOR - TRACKING SHOT - RIKER AND GEORDI

quote: It was a first contact situation.
The Ghorusdans values are so   complex, and so different, that   the Federation sent along a   specialist. To prevent   misunderstanding.
That was Tam Elbrun? And what   happened was his fault?

Not directly. Board of inquiry   blamed Captain Darson's   carelessness about Ghorusdan   cultural taboos.       But if Elbrun's so good, why   didn't he warn Darson? What was   he there for, if he couldn't sense   that much hostility?
Commander, Geordi... do you ever   feel as if I am not "there?" That   is to say... not "here."
You seem to be all here.
Our destination is the Beta   Stromgren system, following the   path of the Vega Nine probe.
That's twenty-three parsecs beyond   our furthest manned explorations.
That is correct, Commander.   Apparently the probe has   discovered...    (a beat, reacting to     something he sees on     the screen)   ...Astonishing.
This is the star Beta Stromgren...

Scientists have discovered that   it is in the final stages of an   alternating cycle of expansion   and collapse, which will soon   result in a supernova.       However, the long-range unmanned   probe which Starfleet sent to   observe the process has discovered   something much more --
Oh, Data -- don't waste time.
They call it "Tin Man". The Vega   Probe found it orbiting Stromgren.
Looks like a ship of some kind.
Its energy source is unknown.   The people who've studied the   transmissions think it's a   starship. And they're sure it's   alive.
Alive? How so?
A cybernetic organism -- like the   Borg?
No, no, NO! Here --
Starfleet believes it's an   organic creature, born in space,   living its life in the wastes   between stars.
No one knows where it came from,   or why it's here now. And we're   going to meet it. We're going   to talk to it.    (softly, as if to     himself)   I'm going to talk to it.
Have attempts been made --
To communicate with it by   subspace. Of course --   linguacode, universal translation,   all that. It won't work. Tin Man   is too different. Direct   mind-to-mind contact is our only   hope.
The opportunity for discovery is   extraordinary -- but I don't yet   understand Starfleet's urgency   --
The Romulans --
Hell, I forgot -- the Romulans...
They claim the sector of space   in which Beta Stromgren is   located.
The Romulans claim all that is   within their field of vision.
And they routinely monitor the   telemetry of our deep-space   probes.
So it's quite certain they'll   be sending a ship of their own   to investigate this Tin Man.
No... Actually, they're sending   two. Uh, Data --

That is correct. Starbase one   twenty-three detected two   D'daridex class cruisers on an   intercept course.       The top speed of this class vessel   is known to be less than our own,   sir. We therefore have some   advantage.

So, it's a race?       An alien intelligence -- a new   life-form -- representing a   technology far beyond that of   either the Romulans or ourselves.   The Romulans will take whatever   measures -- military or otherwise   -- are required to secure the   creature for study.
Study as in dissect, I'd bet.
Data, you're our resident honor   student in exobiology. I'm   assigning you to head up life   sciences on this mission.
Yes, sir.
Excellent.
Meeting adjourned, then.
So, Data -- I guess you're the   brains of this outfit, huh?

Mister Elbrun -- one reason I want   you to work closely with a member   of my staff is to avoid any   further... omissions. The   possibility of an encounter with   Romulans on this mission is hardly   trivial. Yet you --
All right, all right... I should   have brought up the Romulans   earlier, but I was distracted.
And no, Billy boy, I wasn't   "distracted" on Ghorusda.
If Darson had listened to me, no   one would have died. And I   don't care whether you believe   that or not.
Captain's log, Stardate 43782.6.   Travelling at top warp, we are   still several days from rendezvous   with the mysterious entity which   Starfleet has christened Tin Man.
My immediate concern is with Tam   Elbrun. Starfleet considers his   unique abilities crucial to our   mission. Yet he seems to me...   unstable.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: Well, according to his medical   records and psych profile, he's   very high on the ESP scale. A   sort of prodigy.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: A prodigy? In what sense?
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: In most Betazoids their telepathic   gifts develop at adolescence.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: They're not born reading minds?
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: No. Except... for some reason   that no one understands,   occasionally a Betazoid child is   born different.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: How "different?"
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: Born with their telepathic   abilities "switched on."   Most Betazoids born like that   never lead a normal life.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: The noise of other people's   thoughts and feelings must be...   overwhelming. Incomprehensible...   especially for a child.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: And painful. Early diagnosis and   special training helped Tam adjust   -- but he has some problems.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: You mentioned a hospitalization   --
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: For stress. Repeatedly,   throughout his life.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: I always wonder... what holds one   person together through that kind   of struggle, while another goes   under?
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: Yes, well, he's evidently done   more than "hold together". He's   the indispensable man -- the   Federation's finest specialist   in communication with unknown   life-forms.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: It looks like the more unusual a   life form is, the better he likes   it. His personnel file shows that   he's gravitated toward assignments   that isolate him from other   humanoids.
scene: 30   INT. SICKBAY - BEVERLY'S OFFICE - WIDE SHOT

quote: Commander Data, I'm picking up   an unusual echo from my   navigational sensors.
There is something there, sir,   tracking us -- matching our speed   and heading. Something which   doesn't fully register on our   instruments.

Since there is no known natural   phenomenon capable of travel at   warp velocities, there are but   two possibilities: either it is   a sensor malfunction, or it is   another ship, following us   covertly.
It is not a sensor malfunction.
Agreed.
A Romulan ship? With their   cloaking device, we shouldn't pick   them up at all.
Unless they're pulling so much   power for something else that they   can't fully cloak.
Like what?
Ask the Romulans... if it is the   Romulans.
Lieutenant, continue monitoring   the precise position of the echo   -- at any sudden change in its   behavior, initiate Yellow Alert.
Aye, sir.
Come in.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: How're things in the land of the   living?
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: I thought you might be lonely.   No one sees you, except Data.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Lonely? I can hear everything   that everyone on this ship thinks.       No one besides you seems to be   missing my charming --
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: You want them to dislike you.   Why?
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Because I'm not a nice guy?       Okay -- because they scare me.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Too many minds, Deanna. I can't   shut them out -- never could   learn. All their loves, their   hates, their fears, their...   needs. It's like a tide that   never ebbs.       I could drown.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: I remember.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: (smiling in     remembrance.)   You understood -- at least a   little -- how I felt.       I see you finally found a place   to fit... people to care about...
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: And you're still looking.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: (he stands and begins     to pace)   Then there's Ghorusda. I've got   enough doubts about my...   reliability... without having to   listen to Riker's, and Picard's   --
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: What happened there?
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: I thought everyone knew --
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: No. What happened to you?
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Maybe... I got too involved with   the Ghorusdans, with their point   of view. It happens to me. I   wanted everyone to get along.   I could have warned Darson more   forcefully.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: So after that, you ran away? The   last I heard, you were the only   Federation delegate assigned to   Chandra Five.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Beautiful creatures, the   Chandrans. Their minds are   glacial. They have a lovely   three-day ritual for saying   "hello." Peaceful, untroubled   people...
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Unlike humanoids?
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Well, except for your friend Data.   I like him. He's... restful.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: I believe your impression of Data   is probably unique.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Yeah? Well, having to get to know   someone, just once, has its appeal.   I mean, talking to them, instead   of getting it all at once up here   --       -- whether I want it or not.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: But you accepted this mission.   You could have stayed on Chandra   Five. You willingly came aboard   a ship of over a thousand people   --
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: How could I not? Think of it,   Dee. This intelligence that swims   naked through space like a fish   in the sea. Totally alien,   mysterious -- not like us at all.   Ancient. And alone.    (quietly, as if to     himself)   So lonely, for so long.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: How can you know that? Tam?
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: You're in contact with it. With   Tin Man. Aren't you?
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: No -- well... yes. A little.   Not quite on a conscious level.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: But we're still light-years away.   That must be impossible -- even   for you.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Impossible for me. Maybe not   impossible for Tin Man.
scene: 34   INT. TAM ELBRUN'S GUEST QUARTERS (OPTICAL) - TAM

quote: Status, Number One?
We've reached the outer regions   of the Beta Stromgren system, sir.   On course for orbital intercept   of Tin Man, e.t.a. eighteen minutes.
Grand.
Not altogether. Astrophysics   reports that the star's rate of   collapse is increasing -- it could   go supernova within the next few   days.
Captain, we are receiving relayed   sensor data, from the Vega Probe   -- including visuals.
On screen, Mister Data.
Magnify.
Remarkable. Computer -- locate   Tam Elbrun.
Tam Elbrun is in Turbolift One,   en route to the Main Bridge.
Of course.
Commander...
Problem, Worf?
Sir, I am reading a wave front   of ionized particles preceding   the object which is tracking us.
Go to Yellow Alert.
On screen.
Romulan warbird, closing.       They're arming main distruptors,   Captain.
Go to Red Alert -- shields at   maximum.
Worf, arm photon torpedoes and   stand by.
Aye, sir.
I thought you said the Enterprise   was faster than this Romulan --
In fact, we are, Commander.   However --
Evasive, Mister Worf. Data, open   hailing frequencies --
I guarantee that they don't want   to talk to you, Captain.
The Romulan has passed us, sir,   and recloaked.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: Damage report.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: No casualties reported. Seventy   percent loss to main shields, sir.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: Captain, their attack on us was   incidental.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: Incidental?
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: Yes. To delay us.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: Captain, it would appear that the   Romulan's intent is to contact   Tin Man first, at any cost.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: According to my sensor readings,   the warbird exceeded maximum   engine output by nearly thirty   percent... They appear to have   suffered irreparable damage to   their warp coils.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: So -- they kept up with us by   sacrificing their ability to   return to Romulan space.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: A one-way trip.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: There is one more trailing us,   Captain -- a day or two behind.   Data's right -- this one's job   is to beat us to Tin Man at any   cost.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: You read all this, telepathically   --
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: -- In the mind of the Romulan   commander, during the attack.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: Very well, then. Mister Crusher   all stop.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: Aye, sir.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: Commander La Forge.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: La Forge here.
scene: 48A  EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND ROMULAN VESSEL (OPTIZCAL)

quote: Geordi -- how long to restore   shields?
Working on it. Computer,   reconfigure structural integrity   power to feed inner deflector   grid.
Unable to comply. Requested   reroute would compromise   operational safety limits.
To hell with the limits.   Override. Authorization La Forge   theta two-nine-nine-seven.
Rerouting structural integrity   power supply.
(yells to supernumerary     in next room)   Russell! Watch the lateral grid   balance.       Nope, too much. We gotta do it   manually.       La Forge to bridge.
Go ahead.
Captain, I'm trying to feed the   inner grid by stealing some power   from the structural integrity   field. You should have partial   shielding in thirty minutes.
You have ten.
Picard out.    (to the group in     general)   The Romulans wish the honor of   the first contact, let them have   it.
You're out of your mind, Picard!   What if the Romulans find a way   to persuade Tin Man --
I think the chances of that are   remote. And, Mister Elbrun, if   you'll be still you may learn --
What?
That being first, at any cost,   is not always the point.
Data, while we await repairs, I   want Life Sciences and Engineering   to continue collecting information   on the alien. Query the Vega Nine   probe, and the long-range sensors.
Yes, sir.
You do a lot of your work here?
Yes. I have configured these   instruments to display information   with greater speed and efficiency   than stations used by the others.
Nice. A little Spartan.
Spartan?
Lots of work space, not much room   to live. I don't guess you sleep?
I have tried it, from time to   time. But you are correct. I   do not require rest.
But you paint.
The creature's anatomy appears   most peculiar.
In what way?

It is indeed laid out as a vessel,   with what appear to be corridors   and chambers. An internal   environment suitable for carbon   based life forms is being   maintained. Yet there is no   evidence of a crew aboard.       Tin Man is a living being yet it   was bred or adapted itself to   serve a purpose. I find that very   interesting.
Why? Must living beings have a   purpose? Or do we exist for no   reason but to exist?
I do not believe I am qualified   to express an opinion.

Ah, Data -- you're uniquely   qualified. You think a great deal   about humanity -- and you're an   honest researcher. You don't   treat anything as trivial, or   irrelevant. You want to try it   all.
You said in the Transporter Room   that you could not read my mind.
True enough. But I think I   understand you pretty well.       It worries you -- that I can't   read your mind?
Perhaps there is nothing to read.   Nothing other than mechanism and   algorithmic response --
Perhaps you're just different.   Not a sin, you know -- though you   may have heard otherwise.
Captain, the Romulan ship is   hailing the alien using their   equivalent of linguacode.
Response?
None so far, Commander.
Why should it answer? What can   it have in common with them?
But you're so sure it'll "talk" to   you.
Well, I --
Captain, the Romulans are arming   all disruptors.
Yellow Alert. Prepare for evasive   action at the first change in the   Romulans' course.
With our shields in their present   condition, we can't risk --
No!
We're not the target. It's Tin   Man --
What do you mean? They intend   to destroy it?
Those are their orders if they   can't secure the alien.
Increase speed to intercept the   Romulans.
Their lead is too great.
Worf, hail them. I cannot allow   --
They won't listen to you!
Danger... Gom-tuu... Do not allow!
Worf! Damage report!
Not yet available, Captain. We   have partial failure of the main   computer.
You did this. You woke your Tin   Man.
We've got impulse power, but I've   got to take the warp engines off   line while we recalibrate the   intermix regulators.
How long?
For just the warp drive, or for   everything?
All of it.
We're looking at twenty hours   work, double shifts.
Geordi, we don't know that we have   twenty hours. The star could   explode at any time --
I know. Okay, first we need to   get the main computer working   right --
No -- fix the shields first.
Commander, whatever Tin Man hit   us with, it fried circuits I   thought were unfryable.
It's not Tin Man I'm worried   about. It's more Romulans showing   up.
Right. First priority, get the   shields up. Only, let's not have   any more surprises till I'm done.
Don't ask me about surprises.   Ask Tam Elbrun.
Brain activity suggests that   you're coming out of a sort of   fugue, or seizure... blood   pressure and glucose indicative   of general systemic stress --
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: But I'm gonna live?
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: No doubt about it.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Good. I want to know exactly what   you did. I want to know how   closely you are in communication   with the alien, and what you've   learned about it. Now.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: I... just warned it, that's all.   I've been in contact with it...   sensing impressions from it...       It calls itself Gomtuu. It's old,   Captain. It's roamed the universe   for many thousands of years.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Where did it come from? How   many...
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Far away, I think. Maybe beyond   the galaxy. Once there were   millions of them.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Once?
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: It hasn't seen another of its kind   for millennia. It's alone. It   may be the last of its species.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Perhaps we can help it in some   way. Can you ask it to return   with us to Federation space? Or   at least to remove itself from   the vicinity of Beta Stromgren,   before the star explodes?
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Captain, Gomtuu knows that the   star will go nova soon. That's   why it came here. It wants to die.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Why?
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: There was... an explosion, in   space... radiation penetrated   the outer layers. The crew...   the crew died. Such loss... empty   pain... Hollowness.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Stop this! Tam -- Tam, you're   losing yourself in this -- this   merging.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: I -- I know.       Tin Man hurts... and wants to die.       I can't do any more from here.   If you want me to really reach   Tin Man, I've got to be in   physical contact. I've got to   go aboard.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: No. Absolutely out of the   question.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: You don't trust me.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: No. I don't believe that I do.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Tam -- when you reached out to   the alien, to warn it -- did you   give any thought to this vessel?   To the danger, however   inadvertent, the creature might   pose to our crew? Or did you   simply react out of instinct?
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Captain --
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Deanna -- he's right... I don't   know what might happen -- but if   you don't let me go, we fail in   our mission.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Besides, at this point, you need   all the help you can get -- even   Tin Man's.
scene: 81   INT. SICK BAY - ANGLE ON TAM ELBRUN

quote: Russell -- reactivate the sensor   assemblies.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Okay, let's do a program reload   on the port array only.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Good. Computer, run level two   diagnostic.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Port sensor array remains offline.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Damn.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Riker to La Forge. How's it   coming?
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Not great... I think all the   control processors are shot.   Maybe if I swap the chips from   the secondary array, I can give   you a minimum EM scan.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Do it.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Russell -- try restarting sensor   element thirty-two only.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Well, the good news is that we   have partial long range sensors.    (he taps his     communicator)   La Forge to bridge.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: Riker here.
scene: 86   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - ANGLE ON GEORDI

quote: I'm picking up another echo on   the long-range sensor display   here. You getting that on your   panel?
Worf?
One moment, Commander.
Confirmed. Sir, the other Romulan   ship... on an intercept course.
Geordi, are we gonna have shields   anytime soon?
I'm doing the best I can...   But shields won't help if that   star explodes.
Data, you and Tam Elbrun seem to   have developed an affinity. Troi,   you've known him for years. How   far can he be trusted?
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Captain, the issue isn't one of   trust in Tam's intentions, but   in his judgment. I would trust   him to do what he believes is   right --
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Yes, of course. But his   judgment...
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: ... Is precarious. The stress of   exposure to so many minds on the   ship has been bad enough. Now   he's strongly drawn to this   creature. I'm afraid for him.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Afraid of what?
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: I sense that the alien is somehow   calling him. If we allow him to   do as he insists -- to beam over   -- I'm afraid that we'll lose him   to it.       That he will lose himself.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Captain, I agree that Tam's   motives are trustworthy. I do   not believe it is possible that   he might act against us, or cause   Tin Man to act against us out of   malice.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: If Tam breaks down over there,   we'll be no closer to   accomplishing our mission,   Captain. It would be a grave   mistake.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Thank you both.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Captain, the Romulan has   uncloaked.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Data?
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: I am puzzled, sir. We have come   this far. But you may not allow   Tam to fulfill his mission.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Data -- Elbrun warned Tin Man,   and the first thing it did was   to destroy a space vessel.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: I think I understand, sir.       If you feel that the risk is too   great to send Tam Elbrun, alone,   then send me with him.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Counselor Troi understands him   better.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: But I distress him less.       It is humanity he is fleeing.   I can serve as an intermediary...   a bridge back, and a reminder of   his obligations... both to us   and to Tin Man.
scene: 91   INT. CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - WIDE ANGLE FAVORING PICARD

quote: Status Number One?
Shields at forty percent, Captain.   We can maneuver on impulse.
Phasers available on manual, sir.   computer target lock not   functioning.
Well, let's hope they're in a mood   to talk. Open hailing   frequencies.
Romulan vessel -- this is Captain   Jean-Luc Picard of the USS   Enterprise.
Enterprise -- your presence here   is a violation of Romulan space.   You will leave immediately.
We are not familiar with the terms   of your claim on this sector,   Commander. We are here engaged   in scientific research. Do you   wish to participate --
We have monitored the destruction   of our sister ship by the star   creature. We claim right of   vengeance. We will destroy the   alien.       If you interfere, we will destroy   you as well.

Captain's log, Supplemental.   Light-years beyond the edges of   explored space, and virtually   disabled, our survival may now   depend upon Tam Elbrun's   telepathic rapport with an alien   intelligence.
scene: 100  EXT. SPACE - THE ENTERPRISE AND THE ROMULAN SHIP

quote: Picard to Tam Elbrun.
Captain?
Report to Transporter Room Six   immediately.
Captain, I don't --
Commander Data will meet you   there.
Counselor, we no longer have a   choice.
No... Too much. Too much.
scene: 107  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - WIDE ANGLE (OPTICAL)

quote: Tam?
scene: 107  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - WIDE ANGLE (OPTICAL)

quote: I can't.
scene: 107  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - WIDE ANGLE (OPTICAL)

quote: Data to Enterprise. Come in   Enterprise.
scene: 107  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - WIDE ANGLE (OPTICAL)

quote: No... No, don't.
scene: 107  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - WIDE ANGLE (OPTICAL)

quote: If it is harming you, we must   return.
scene: 107  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - WIDE ANGLE (OPTICAL)

quote: Enterprise, respond.
scene: 107  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - WIDE ANGLE (OPTICAL)

quote: I cannot contact the ship.
scene: 107  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - WIDE ANGLE (OPTICAL)

quote: It's alright... Gomtuu tried to   communicate a lifetime of   experiences to me in a few   seconds.       It's alright now.
scene: 107  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - WIDE ANGLE (OPTICAL)

quote: O'Brien to bridge.
scene: 109  INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - ANGLE ON O'BRIEN

quote: Go ahead, Chief.
scene: 110  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: I lost the transporter lock on   them. Some kind of force field   went up.
scene: 110  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Confirmed. The alien has thrown   up a shield -- it's blocking all   our sensors.
scene: 110  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: The Romulans' weapons systems are   now at full power.
scene: 110  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Red Alert... Mister Worf... arm   photon torpedos.
Yes...
scene: 115  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - ANGLE ON TAM

quote: There is a large chamber twenty   meters ahead.
scene: 115  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - ANGLE ON TAM

quote: Yeah, I know.
scene: 115  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - ANGLE ON TAM

quote: I know everything, now. Come on.
scene: 115  INT. TIN MAN CORRIDOR - ANGLE ON TAM

quote: Intriguing.
This is the control center where   Gomtuu's crew guided their   journeys. The ship and the crew   existed symbiotically.
They needed one another. When   Gomtuu had no one left to care   for, it no longer had a reason   to exist.
(recalling their earlier     talk)   And is that the purpose of   existence? To care for someone?
It is for me.       Deanna was right. I'll lose   myself here.
An invitation.
I must remind you that our   objective is to bring Tin Man out   of danger and report our findings   to Starfleet.
I'm not going back, Data. I'm   staying here.
Captain Picard, if you interfere   with us, we will fire upon you   as well --
scene: 123  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE FAVORING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Commander -- we are prepared to   defend the life of the alien.       Shields up.
scene: 123  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE FAVORING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Power levels aboard the alien are   increasing, sir.
scene: 123  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE FAVORING MAIN VIEWER

quote: (stepping on Worf's line     in his urgency)   Captain, the diameter of the star   has decreased by one hundred   thousand kilometers.
scene: 123  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE FAVORING MAIN VIEWER

quote: It's beginning.
scene: 123  INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE FAVORING MAIN VIEWER

quote: (turning to look at     Data)   Explain to them... make them   understand.
But our mission...

... is to save Tin Man and I   will... but he's going to save   me as well. All my life I've   waited for this. A chance to   find peace. Finally all the   the voices are silent. Only Tin   Man speaks to me now.       Don't you see, Data? This is   where I belong.
The star is gonna go any minute,   sir.
The Romulans know that as well   as we do.
Power levels aboard Tin Man   increasing beyond our sensor   range.
Conn -- report.
Dead stop, Captain. Sir--    (pause as he     double-checks readings)   We've been thrown clear of Beta   Stromgren. Distance -- three   point eight billion kilometers.
There is no sign of Tin Man or   the Romulans, sir.       Captain -- on screen!
Data.
Sir?
Data -- what happened, over there?
Difficult to explain, Captain.
Tam?
I believe he has found what he   was looking for, Counselor.
Captain's log, supplemental. With   all main systems at least   temporarily restored, we are   proceeding to Starbase one fifty-two    for inspection and additional repairs.
We have had no further encounter   with the Romulans. As for the   whereabouts of Tin Man, and Tam   Elbrun -- we can only speculate.
You sent for me?
Tam's final request was for me   to explain his decision to the   crew. But I believe his hope was   that you would understand.
What did happen, Data?
I witnessed something remarkable.       Individually they were both so...
Wounded? Incomplete?
Yes. But no longer. Through   their joining they have been   healed. Grief was transmuted to   joy. Loneliness to belonging.
Data, you do understand...
Yes, Counselor, when Tin Man   returned me to the Enterprise I   realized that this was where I   belong.
